content.description: Positive rotation angles mean we turn counterclockwise. Negative angles are clockwise. We can think of a 60 degree turn as 1/3 of a 180 degree turn. A 90 degree turn is 1/4 of the way around a full circle. The angle goes from the center to first point, then from the center to the image of the point.
content.descriptionHtml: Positive rotation angles mean we turn counterclockwise. Negative angles are clockwise. We can think of a 60 degree turn as 1/3 of a 180 degree turn. A 90 degree turn is 1/4 of the way around a full circle. The angle goes from the center to first point, then from the center to the image of the point.

that point P was rotated
about the origin (0,0) by 60 degrees.
Which point is the image of P?

Pause this video and see
if you can figure that out.
All right, now let's think about it.
This is point P.
It's being rotated around the origin
(0,0) by 60 degrees.

So if originally point
P is right over here
and we're rotating by positive 60 degrees,

so that means we go counter
clockwise by 60 degrees.

So this looks like about
60 degrees right over here.
One way to think about 60 degrees,
is that that's 1/3 of 180 degrees.
So does this look like 1/3 of 180 degrees?

Remember, 180 degrees would
be almost a full line.

So that indeed does look
like 1/3 of 180 degrees,
60 degrees, it gets us to point C.
And it looks like it's the same distance
from the origin.
We have just rotated by 60 degrees.

Point D looks like it's more
than 60 degree rotation,
so I won't go with that one.
All right, let's do one more of these.

So we're told point P was
rotated by negative 90 degrees.
The center of rotation is indicated.
Which point is the image of P?
So once again, pause this video
and try to think about it.

All right, so we have
our center of rotation,
this is our point P,
and we're rotating by negative 90 degrees.
So this means we are going clockwise.
So we're going in that direction.
And 90 degrees is easy to spot.
It's a right angle.

And so it would look like
that and it looks like
it is getting us right to point A.

So this is a negative 90 degree
rotation right over here.
Gets us to point A.

content.translatedDescription: Positive rotation angles mean we turn counterclockwise. Negative angles are clockwise. We can think of a 60 degree turn as 1/3 of a 180 degree turn. A 90 degree turn is 1/4 of the way around a full circle. The angle goes from the center to first point, then from the center to the image of the point.
content.translatedDescriptionHtml: Positive rotation angles mean we turn counterclockwise. Negative angles are clockwise. We can think of a 60 degree turn as 1/3 of a 180 degree turn. A 90 degree turn is 1/4 of the way around a full circle. The angle goes from the center to first point, then from the center to the image of the point.

course.translatedDescription: Learn high school geometry—transformations, congruence, similarity, trigonometry, analytic geometry, and more. (aligned with Common Core standards)

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Identifying points, identifying number opposites, estimating angles, and calculating distance help prepare us to perform transformations.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Euclid as the father of geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Euclid, often called the father of geometry, changed the way we learn about shapes with his 13-book series, Euclid's Elements. He used basic ideas called axioms or postulates to create solid proofs and figure out new ideas called theorems and propositions. Studying Euclidean geometry helps us think better and solve problems more effectively.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Euclid as the father of geometry

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Terms & labels in geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Explore geometry fundamentals, including points, line segments, rays, and lines. Understand dimensions and how these elements form shapes and patterns. Learn key geometric terms like colinear points, midpoints, and vertices, and enhance your knowledge of geometry. Improve your skills and discover the world of shapes and space.

Using precise language is important in geometry, as it allows for clear communication and understanding of geometric concepts. This video provides an interactive exercise that emphasizes the significance of accurate definitions, helping learners develop their mathematical communication skills and enhance their grasp of geometry.
Communicate clearly by using complete definitions for geometric terms.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Intro to geometric transformations
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Transformations in math involve changing a shape's position or which way the shape points. There are three main types: translations (moving the shape), rotations (turning the shape), and reflections (flipping the shape like a mirror image). Rigid transformations keep the shape's size and angles the same. The image is the shape in its new position and direction.

Dilations are a type of non-rigid transformation. They change the size of a shape by scaling it up or down, making it bigger or smaller. Unlike rigid transformations, dilations do not keep the shape's size the same.
Learn what translations are and how to perform them in our interactive widget.
Learn what rotations are and how to perform them in our interactive widget.

Let's look at four types of transformations: rotations (spinning a shape around a point), translations (shifting a shape), reflections (flipping a shape over a line), and dilations (shrinking or expanding a shape). We practice identifying these transformations in different pairs of figures.
Identify the transformation (translation, rotation, reflection, or dilation) that has been applied to a figure.

Let's practice translations on a coordinate plane. A translation is a way to move a point or shape by a certain number of units in a certain direction. For example, we can translate a point by moving it 5 units left and 3 units up. We describe this translation algebraically using the coordinates (x-5, y+3).

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Translate points | Algebra
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given a point and a definition of a translation, plot the translation on a coordinate plane or identify the coordinates of the translated point.

We can find the translation by figuring out how much the x- and y-coordinates need to change to map one triangle onto the other. We map each point to its corresponding point in the other triangle. Moving left means the translation of x is negative, and moving down means the translation of y is negative.
Learn how to find the necessary translation to map a given source shape onto a given image shape.
Given two figures on the coordinate plane, find the formal definition of the translation that takes one figure to another.

In translations, we slide a shape around on a grid. We use the letter "T" to represent translations. We move every point of the shape a certain distance left or right, and up or down, to create a new shape that's the same size and shape as the original. We call the new shape the image.
Learn how to draw the image of a given shape under a given translation.
Given a figure and a definition of a translation, manually draw the image.
A translation acting on the coordinate plane takes the point (-169,434) to point (-203, -68). What are the coordinates of the image of point (31, -529) under this translation?

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Properties of translations | Geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Experimentally verify the effect of geometric translations on segment length, angle measure, and parallel lines.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Positive rotation angles mean we turn counterclockwise. Negative angles are clockwise. We can think of a 60 degree turn as 1/3 of a 180 degree turn. A 90 degree turn is 1/4 of the way around a full circle. The angle goes from the center to first point, then from the center to the image of the point.
Given a point and a definition of a rotation, plot the rotation on a coordinate plane or identify the coordinates of the rotated point.

To see the angle of rotation, we draw lines from the center to the same point in the shape before and after the rotation. Counterclockwise rotations have positive angles, while clockwise rotations have negative angles. Then we estimate the angle. For example, 30 degrees is 1/3 of a right angle.
Learn how to determine which rotation brings one given shape to another given shape.
Given a figure on the coordinate plane and a center of a rotation, find the angle for the rotation that maps one figure to the other.
Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, and he manually draws the image of that rotation.
Learn how to draw the image of a given shape under a given rotation about the origin by any multiple of 90°.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Rotating shapes about the origin by multiples of 90°

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given a figure on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, manually draw the image of that rotation.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: We can plot points after reflecting them across a line, like the x-axis or y-axis. Reflections create mirror images of points, keeping the same distance from the line. When we reflect across the y-axis, the image point is the same height, but has the opposite position from left to right.
Given a point and a definition of a horizontal or vertical reflection, plot the reflection on a coordinate plane or identify the coordinates of the reflected point.

A line of reflection is an imaginary line that flips one shape onto another. We find this line by finding the halfway points between matching points on the source and image triangles. All of the halfway points are on the line. Once we find that line, it shows how one triangle reflects onto the other.
Given a shape and its image under a horizontal or vertical reflection, determine the line of reflection.
Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane, and determines the reflection that maps one of them into the other.
Given two figures on the coordinate plane, draw the line of reflection that takes one figure to another.

Let's reflect a quadrilateral across the x-axis. To do this, we find new points (A', B', C', D') by keeping the same x-coordinates and changing the y-coordinates to their opposite signs. This creates a flipped image of the original quadrilateral.
Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane and the definition of a reflection, and he draws the image of the segments under that reflection.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Reflecting shapes: diagonal line of reflection

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Learn how to find the image of a given reflection.
Given a figure and a definition of a reflection, manually draw the image.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Dilations are a way to stretch or shrink shapes around a point called the center of dilation. The amount we stretch or shrink is called the scale factor. If the scale factor is greater than 1, the shape stretches. If it's between 0 and 1, the shape shrinks.
Use the interactive transformation tool to perform dilations.

Dilations make a shape bigger or smaller. A scale factor tells us how much to multiply by the side lengths to change the size. The scale factor is the ratio of the side length in the new shape (image) to the side length in the corresponding side in the original shape (pre-image). Each pair of corresponding sides has the same factor.
Find both the center and the scale factor of a dilation that maps a given figure to another one.
Determining the center of dilation, given a figure and its image under a dilation.
Given a figure and its image under a dilation, determine the dilation's center point.

Let's dilate a rectangle around a point P using a scale factor 1 2/3. This changes the size of the rectangle while keeping its shape. Because 1 2/3 is bigger than 1, most of the points get farther from P. Point P stays in place, because a distance of 0 times any scale factor is still 0.
Draw the image of the triangle under a dilation with scale factor 1/4 about the center of dilation on the coordinate plane.
Dilating doesn't just shrink or grow a figure. The scale factor also changes the distance from each point to the center of dilation.
Given a figure and a definition of a dilation, select or manually draw the image.
Frequently asked questions about performing transformations

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

unitChildren.translatedDescription:
In this topic you will learn about the most useful math concept for creating video game graphics: geometric transformations, specifically translations, rotations, reflections, and dilations.

You will learn how to perform the transformations, and how to map one figure into another using these transformations.

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Finding missing triangle angle measures, area and perimeter, and angle measures on transversals help prepare us to learn the properties of transformations.

Finding measures after a rigid transformation, like a reflection, is pretty simple! Since the shape and size stay the same, the lengths of corresponding sides and angle measures remain unchanged. Area and perimeter depend on the side lengths, so they stay the same too. So, if we know the measures of the original figure, we can use those same measures for the transformed figure.
Use your knowledge about the effects of rigid transformations to solve problems about figures and their images under transformations.

Rigid transformations, like rotations and reflections, change a shape's position but keep its size and shape. These transformations preserve side lengths, angle measures, perimeter, and area. But they might not keep the same coordinates or relationships to lines outside the figure.
Identify which properties of shapes remain the same after a rigid transformation (reflection, rotation, translation) has been applied.

Let's find the right sequence of rigid transformations (like rotations, translations, and reflections) to map one triangle onto another. Different sequences can work, but order matters. So, it's important to test each one to see if it maps the triangles correctly.
Describe sequences of rigid transformations (translations, rotations, and/or reflections) that will map a given shape onto another.
What properties of a shape are preserved or not preserved after a dilation?
Given a shape and the dilation that is performed on it, determine which properties the shape and its image share.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Determining whether segment lengths and angle measures are preserved under a given sequence of transformations.
Given a description of a sequence of transformations, determine whether it preserves segment length or angle measure.
Given a description of the effect of a certain transformation, we determine whether that transformation is a translation, a rotation, or a reflection.
Read a dialog where a student and a teacher work towards defining rotations as precisely as possible.
Refine definitions of rigid transformations. Given a description of the effect of a transformation, determine which rigid transformation it is.
Sal is given information about a transformation in terms of a few pairs of points and their corresponding images, and he determines what kind of transformation it can be.
Introduction to the concept of an "axis of symmetry"
Analyze various shapes according to their reflective symmetries.
Sal checks whether various figure are symmetrical under a 180 degrees rotation.
Identify rotational symmetry in figures by determining magnitudes of rotations which map a figure onto itself.
Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (0,9) and (3,4). The quadrilateral has reflective symmetry over the line y=3-x. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Finding a quadrilateral from its symmetries

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (-4,-2) and (0,5). The quadrilateral has a reflective symmetry over the lines y=x/2 and y=-2x+5. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Finding a quadrilateral from its symmetries (example 2)

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Prove theorems about lines and angles using transformations.
Frequently asked questions about transformation properties and proofs

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.
allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Transformation properties and proofs: Unit test

unitChildren.translatedDescription: Let's carefully define translations, reflections, rotations, and dilations. What stays the same when we transform figures?

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Finding missing triangle angle measures and identifying parallel lines from angle measures on transversals help prepare us to learn about congruence.

If we can map one figure onto another using rigid transformations, they are congruent. They are still congruent if we need to use more than one transformation to map it. They aren't if we use a transformation that changes the size of the shape.

Congruent shapes are the same size and shape. Rigid transformations, like translations, keep shapes congruent, but dilations are not rigid transformations because they change the size. So, if we use a dilation to map one shape onto another, they are not congruent.
Given a pair of figures in the coordinate plane, determine whether they are congruent based on whether it is possible to map one to the other using rigid transformations.
Two line segments are congruent if and only if they have equal lengths
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Segment congruence equivalent to having same length

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Two angles are congruent if and only if they have the same measure.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Angle congruence equivalent to having same measure

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: We can prove the side-side-side (SSS) triangle congruence criterion using the rigid transformation definition of congruence.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proving the SSS triangle congruence criterion using transformations

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: We can prove the side-angle-side (SAS) triangle congruence criterion using the rigid transformation definition of congruence.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proving the SAS triangle congruence criterion using transformations

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: We can prove the angle-side-angle (ASA) and angle-angle-side (AAS) triangle congruence criteria using the rigid transformation definition of congruence.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proving the ASA and AAS triangle congruence criteria using transformations

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: There are some cases when SSA can imply triangle congruence, but not always. This is why it's not like the other triangle congruence postulates/criteria.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Why SSA isn't a congruence postulate/criterion

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Justify the criteria for triangle congruence (ASA, SAS, and SSS) using rigid transformations.
Sal introduces and justifies the SSS, SAS, ASA and AAS postulates for congruent triangles. He also shows that AAA is only good for similarity. For SSA, better to watch next video.
Sal uses the SSS, ASA, SAS, and AAS postulates to find congruent triangles.
Calculate missing angle measures to determine which triangles must be congruent.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Calculating angle measures to verify congruence

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Use the triangle congruence criteria SSS, SAS, ASA, and AAS to determine that two triangles are congruent.
When two triangles are congruent, we can know that all of their corresponding sides and angles are congruent too!
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Corresponding parts of congruent triangles are congruent

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given a figure composed of 2 triangles, prove that the triangles are congruent or determine that there's not enough information to tell.
Given figures composed of 2 triangles, complete or find the error in the proof that the triangles are congruent.
Review the triangle congruence criteria and use them to determine congruent triangles.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Learn when to apply the reflexive property, transitive, and symmetric properties in geometric proofs. Learn the relationship between equal measures and congruent figures.

The sum of the interior angle measures of a triangle always adds up to 180°. We can draw a line parallel to the base of any triangle through its third vertex. Then we use transversals, vertical angles, and corresponding angles to rearrange those angle measures into a straight line, proving that they must add up to 180°.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Angles in a triangle sum to 180° proof

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal proves that the base angles in isosceles triangles are congruent, and conversely, that triangles with congruent base angles are isosceles. He also proves that the perpendicular to the base of an isosceles triangle bisects it.
Sal proves that the angles of an equilateral triangle are all congruent (and therefore they all measure 60°), and conversely, that triangles with all congruent angles are equilateral.

An exterior angle is formed outside a triangle by extending a side. Its measure is equal to the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angle measures, thanks to the fact that all angle measures in a triangle add up to 180 degrees.
Use transformations, line and angle relationships, and triangle congruence criteria to prove properties of triangles.
We write the letters of congruent triangles so their order tells us which parts are corresponding. In this video, Sal uses this notation to solve some angles.
Given two triangles, determine whether they are congruent and use that to find missing angle measures.

Isosceles triangles have two congruent sides and two congruent base angles. Equilateral triangles have all side lengths equal and all angle measures equal. We use these properties to find missing angles in composite figures. The problems are partly from Art of Problem Solving, by Richard Rusczyk.
Find missing angles in isosceles triangles given just one angle.
The measures of two angles of an isosceles triangle are 3x+5 and x+16. Find all possible values of x.
Sal combines what we know about isosceles triangles and parallel lines with the power of algebra to solve the angles of an isosceles triangle.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: Opposite sides of a parallelogram

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal proves that a quadrilateral is a parallelogram if and only if its diagonals bisect each other.
Sal proves that opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: Opposite angles of a parallelogram

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal proves that the diagonals of a kite are perpendicular, by using the SSS and SAS triangle congruence criteria.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: The diagonals of a kite are perpendicular

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal proves that the diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular, and that they intersect at the midpoints of both.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: Rhombus diagonals are perpendicular bisectors

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal proves that we can find the area of a rhombus by taking half the product of the lengths of the diagonals.
Use transformations, triangle congruency criteria, and line and angle relationship to prove parallelogram properties.
Sal proves that a point is the midpoint of a segment using triangle congruence.
Sal proves that two pairs of segments are congruent using the ASA and AAS congruence criteria.
Sal finds a missing angle using triangle congruence in a diagram that contains sector of a circle inscribed within a square.
Prove theorems about lines and angles using triangle congruence criteria and algebra.
We can construct congruent angles with a compass and straight edge. They're congruent corresponding angles of congruent triangles.
We can parallel lines with compass and straightedge by creating a pair of congruent corresponding angles on a transversal.
Sal constructs a perpendicular bisector to a given line segment using compass and straightedge.
Sal constructs a line perpendicular to a given line through a point on the line using compass and straightedge.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Geometric constructions: perpendicular line through a point on the line

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: We can construct a perpendicular line through a point off the line. The lines must be perpendicular because a rhombus's diagonals are perpendicular.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Geometric constructions: perpendicular line through a point not on the line

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal constructs a line that bisects a given angle using compass and straightedge.
Use triangle congruence criteria and line and angle relationships to justify geometric constructions of congruent angles, angle and segment bisectors, parallel lines, and perpendicular lines.
Frequently asked questions about congruence

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

unitChildren.translatedDescription: Learn what it means for two figures to be congruent, and how to determine whether two figures are congruent or not. Use this immensely important concept to prove various geometric theorems about triangles and parallelograms.

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Practicing identifying proportional relationships and solving equations with proportions helps us get ready to learn about similarity.

Two shapes are similar if we can change one shape into the other using rigid transformations (like moving or rotating) and dilations (making it bigger or smaller). Other kinds of transformations can change the angles or the ratios of lengths in a figure. If we need those types of transformations, the shapes are not similar.
Given a pair of figures in the coordinate plane, determine whether they are similar based on whether it is possible to map one to the other using angle-preserving transformations.

When we have an equation where the variable is in the denominator of a quotient, that's a rational equation. We can solve it by multiplying both sides by the denominator, but we have to look out for extraneous solutions in the process.
Solve equations that have one rational expression whose numerator and denominator are linear expressions.
Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar, and how this follows from the definition of similarity.
Sal reviews all the different ways we can determine that two triangles are similar. This is similar to the congruence criteria, only for similarity!
Use dilations and rigid transformations to show why a pair of triangles with at least two pairs of congruent corresponding angles must be similar.
Given two triangles with some of their angle measures, determine whether the triangles are similar or not.
Given two triangles with their side measures, determine whether the triangles are similar or not.
Multiple examples where Sal analyzes the similarity of triangles.
Given triangles embedded in a figure, prove whether or not they are similar.
Review the triangle similarity criteria and use them to determine similar triangles.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal solves two problems where a missing side length is found by proving that triangles are similar and using this to find the measure.
Given two similar triangles and some of their side lengths, find a missing side length.
Sal finds a missing side length in a problem where the same side plays different roles in two similar triangles.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Solving similar triangles: same side plays different roles

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given two similar triangles and some of their side lengths, find a missing side length.

The Angle Bisector Theorem states that when an angle in a triangle is split into two equal angles, it divides the opposite side into two parts. The ratio of these parts will be the same as the ratio of the sides next to the angle.
Sal uses the angle bisector theorem to solve for sides of a triangle.
Use the angle bisector theorem to find missing side lengths in triangles.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal uses the similarity of triangles and the congruence of others in this multi-step problem to find the area of a polygon.
Solve geometry problems with various polygons by using all you know about similarity.
Interesting similarity problem where we don't have a lot of information to work with

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Solving problems with similar & congruent triangles

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Proof of the Pythagorean Theorem using similarity

The three midsegments (segments joining the midpoints of the sides) of a triangle form a medial triangle. Find out the properties of the midsegments, the medial triangle and the other 3 triangles formed in this way.
Prove that a line parallel to one triangle side divides other sides proportionately.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: Parallel lines divide triangle sides proportionally

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Using similarity, we can prove the Pythagorean theorem and theorems about segments when a line intersects 2 sides of a triangle.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Proving slope is constant | Algebra
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal uses a clever proof involving similar triangles to show that slope is constant for a line.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proving slope is constant using similarity

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Proof: parallel lines have the same slope | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal proves that parallel lines have the same slope using triangle similarity.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: parallel lines have the same slope

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Proof: perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slope | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: To prove that perpendicular lines have opposite reciprocal slopes, draw the two lines and label key points. By identifying the two right triangles that are formed, one can use the definition of slope to calculate the slopes of the two lines. Finally, using the properties of similar right triangles, show that the two slopes are indeed opposite reciprocals of each other.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: perpendicular lines have opposite reciprocal slopes

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Triangle similarity, the Golden ratio, and art, all converge in this inspiring video!
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Geometry word problem: the golden ratio

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Similarity and the Golden ratio join forces again, this time to save the Earth! (Or maybe just finding its radius)
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Geometry word problem: Earth & Moon radii

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal uses triangle similarity to plan the perfect shot in a pool game.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Geometry word problem: a perfect pool shot

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Frequently asked questions about similarity

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Solving modeling problems with similar & congruent triangles

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

unitChildren.translatedDescription: Learn what it means for two figures to be similar, and how to determine whether two figures are similar or not. Use this concept to prove geometric theorems and solve some problems with polygons.

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Practicing finding right triangle side lengths with the Pythagorean theorem, rewriting square root expressions, and visualizing right triangles in context helps us get ready to learn about right triangles and trigonometry.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Getting ready for right triangles and trigonometry

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Discover how to find the length of an edge in a 3D shape using the Pythagorean theorem! This fun math lesson explores right pyramids and rectangular prisms, guiding you through solving for unknown lengths by applying the theorem multiple times.
Apply the Pythagorean theorem to find lengths in prisms and pyramids.

To find the value of a base (x) in an isosceles triangle, first split the triangle into two congruent right triangles by drawing an altitude. Then, use the Pythagorean theorem to create an equation involving x. Finally, solve the equation to find the unknown base, x.
Use the Pythagorean theorem and proportional reasoning in context.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Multi-step word problem with Pythagorean theorem

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using the Pythagorean Theorem!

Former U.S. President James Garfield wrote a proof of the Pythagorean theorem. He used a trapezoid made of two identical right triangles and half of a square to show that the sum of the squares of the two shorter sides equals the square of the longest side of a right triangle.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean theorem

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: The 12th century Indian mathematician Bhaskara developed an elegant visual proof of the Pythagorean Theorem. Bhaskara uses a square and four congruent right triangles, rearranged in two ways, to prove this theorem. He shows that in a right triangle, the square of the longest side (hypotenuse) is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Bhaskara's proof of the Pythagorean theorem

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Proof of the Pythagorean Theorem using similarity
Visually proving the Pythagorean Theorem
Learn how to prove the ratios between the sides of a 30-60-90 triangle.
Showing the ratios of the sides of a 45-45-90 triangle are 1:1:sqrt(2)
Use the Pythagorean theorem to discover patterns in 30°-60°-90° and 45°-45°-90° triangles.
Using what we know about 30-60-90 triangles to solve what at first seems to be a challenging problem
Using what we know about triangles to find the area of a regular hexagon
Learn shortcut ratios for the side lengths of two common right triangles: 45°-45°-90° and 30°-60°-90° triangles. The ratios come straight from the Pythagorean theorem.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: In a right triangle, the hypotenuse is the longest side, an "opposite" side is the one across from a given angle, and an "adjacent" side is next to a given angle.
By similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Side ratios in right triangles as a function of the angles

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: When two right triangles share an acute angle measure, the ratios of the corresponding side lengths within the triangles are equal.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Using similarity to estimate ratio between side lengths

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Because of similarity, all right triangles with a given acute angle measure have equal ratios between their side lengths. So if we know two of the side lengths of a right triangle, we can figure out the angle measures, too!
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Using right triangle ratios to approximate angle measure

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Relate angles and side lengths using side length ratios in similar right triangles.
Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.
Sal shows a few examples where he starts with the two legs of a right triangle and he finds the trig ratios of one of the acute angles.
Learn how to find the sine, cosine, and tangent of angles in right triangles.
Given the side lengths of a right triangle, find the sine, cosine, or tangent of one of the acute angles.
Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Solving for a side in right triangles with trigonometry

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Learn how to use trig functions to find an unknown side length in a right triangle.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Solving for a side in right triangles with trigonometry

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given one side length and an acute angle in a right triangle, find another side using trigonometry.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Solve for a side in right triangles

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Learn about arcsine, arccosine, and arctangent, and how they can be used to solve for a missing angle in right triangles.
Given two sides in a right triangle, find one of the acute angles using trigonometry.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Solve for an angle in right triangles

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Solving for an angle in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.
Sal solved the following problem: Given that cos(58°)=0.53, find sin(32°).
We can describe the trigonometric ratios from a single right triangle in terms of either acute angle. The relationships hold for all complementary angle pairs.
Sal solves a problem about a submerged pyramid using the fact that the sine of an angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.
Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to match different expressions with different trig values.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Trig challenge problem: trig values & side ratios

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.
Learn what  the terms angle of elevation and angle of depression mean. The words may be big but their meaning is pretty basic!
Solve word problems by modeling real-world (and not-so-real) situations as right triangles and using trigonometry.
Review right triangle trigonometry and how to use it to solve problems.
Frequently asked questions about right triangles and trigonometry

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

unitChildren.translatedDescription: Triangles are not always right (although they are never wrong), but when they are it opens up an exciting world of possibilities.  Not only are right triangles cool in their own right (pun intended), they are the basis of very important ideas in analytic geometry (the distance between two points in space) and trigonometry.

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Analytic geometry relates geometric figures to the coordinate plane and algebraic representations. Let's review the coordinate plane, distance and displacement, slope, and a few helpful arithmetic skills to get ready.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Distance formula | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Learn how to find the distance between two points by using the distance formula, which is an application of the Pythagorean theorem. We can rewrite the Pythagorean theorem as d=√((x_2-x_1)²+(y_2-y_1)²) to find the distance between any two points.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Distance formula | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Walk through deriving a general formula for the distance between two points.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Distance between two points | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the distance between two points on the coordinate plane.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Midpoint formula: how to find midpoint
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Learn how to use the midpoint formula to find the midpoint of a line segment on the coordinate plane, or find the endpoint of a line segment given one point and the midpoint.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Midpoint formula | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Walk through writing a general formula for the midpoint between two points.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Midpoint formula | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Find the midpoint of a segment on the coordinate plane, or find the endpoint of a segment given one point and the midpoint.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Distance formula review | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the distance formula and how to apply it to solve problems.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Midpoint formula review | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the midpoint formula and how to apply it to solve problems.
Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio. A graph is given to make it easier to visualize the problem.
Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio.
Figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that gives a certain ratio. For example, find a point B so that it is two thirds of the way between point A and C.
Prove that for any triangle, the medians intersect at a point 2/3 of the way from each vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proving triangle medians intersect at a point

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal finds the area of a trapezoid using the distance formula and the trapezoid area formula.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Area of trapezoid on the coordinate plane

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Find the area or perimeter of shapes like triangles, rectangles, parallelograms, and hexagons on the coordinate plane.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Area & perimeter on the coordinate plane

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal uses the distance formula to determine whether the point (-6,-6) is inside, outside, or on the circle centered at (-1,-3) with radius 6.
Given the center and radius of a circle, determine if a point is inside of the circle, on the circle, or outside of the circle
Watch Sal solve a challenging problem where he has to determine if points are on both, one, or neither of two circles.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Challenge problem: Points on two circles

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Watch Sal solve an example where has to determine which of the Minions a wizard can reach using the coordinate plane.
Use the coordinate plane to compare distances and areas in applied contexts.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Problem solving with distance on the coordinate plane

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Parallel & perpendicular lines intro | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Parallel & perpendicular lines from graph | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: The slopes of parallel lines are equal, and the slopes of perpendicular lines are opposite reciprocals. This is a worked example of determining whether given lines are parallel or perpendicular.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Parallel & perpendicular lines from graph | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given points that two lines go through or the graph of each line, classify the lines as parallel, perpendicular, or neither.
Watch Sal classify a quadrilateral as a square, rhombus, rectangle, parallelogram, or trapezoid given its four vertices.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Classifying quadrilaterals on the coordinate plane

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Use coordinates to determine the slopes of sides of a figure in order to classify it.
Given the coordinates of a quadrilateral or triangle, determine whether it has the features necessary to be a specific kind of shape, such as a rectangle.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Parallel & perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Parallel lines from equation | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Parallel lines from equation (example 2) | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Parallel lines from equation (example 3) | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Perpendicular lines from equation | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are perpendicular.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Parallel & perpendicular lines from equation | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Use the equations of a pair of lines to decide whether they intersect or not. If yes, are they perpendicular? If no, are they distinct or the same line?

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Writing equations of perpendicular lines | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given line A and point P, Sal finds the equation of the line perpendicular to A that passes through P.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Writing equations of perpendicular lines (example 2) | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal finds the equation of a line perpendicular to a line given in slope-intercept form that passes through a specific point.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Write equations of parallel & perpendicular lines | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Write the equation for a line that is a parallel or perpendicular to a line given in slope-intercept form and goes through a specific point.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Write equations of parallel & perpendicular lines

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Proof: parallel lines have the same slope | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal proves that parallel lines have the same slope using triangle similarity.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: parallel lines have the same slope

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Proof: perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slope | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: To prove that perpendicular lines have opposite reciprocal slopes, draw the two lines and label key points. By identifying the two right triangles that are formed, one can use the definition of slope to calculate the slopes of the two lines. Finally, using the properties of similar right triangles, show that the two slopes are indeed opposite reciprocals of each other.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: perpendicular lines have opposite reciprocal slopes

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Frequently asked questions about analytic geometry

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

unitChildren.translatedDescription: In analytic geometry, also known as coordinate geometry, we think about geometric objects on the coordinate plane. For example, we can see that opposite sides of a parallelogram are parallel by writing a linear equation for each side and seeing that the slopes are the same.

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Practicing finding measurements in a circle, using the Pythagorean theorem, and completing the square will help us get ready for reasoning about conic sections (such as circles and parabolas).
Sal introduces the four conic sections and shows how they are derived by intersecting planes with cones in certain ways.
How to graph a circle given the center and either the radius or another point on the circle.
Given information about the center and radius of a circle, graph it.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Graph a circle from its features

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given a circle on the coordinate plane, Sal finds its center and its radius.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Features of a circle from its graph

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given the graph of a circle, find its center and radius.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Features of a circle from its graph

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Features of a circle from its standard equation | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Features of a circle from its standard equation

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Features of a circle from its standard equation | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Find the center and radius of a circle given the equation in standard form.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Features of a circle from its standard equation

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Graphing a circle from its standard equation | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal graphs the circle whose equation is (x+5)²+(y-5)²=4.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Graphing a circle from its standard equation

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Graph a circle from its standard equation | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given the standard form equation of a circle, graph the circle. For example, graph the circle whose equation is (x+5)²+(y+2)²=4.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Graph a circle from its standard equation

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Writing standard equation of a circle | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given a circle on the coordinate plane, Sal finds its standard equation, which is an equation in the form (x-a)²+(y-b)²=r².
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Writing standard equation of a circle

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Write standard equation of a circle | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given the graph of a circle or its features, find its standard equation.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Write standard equation of a circle

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Features of a circle from its expanded equation | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Features of a circle from its expanded equation

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Features of a circle from its expanded equation | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Find the center and radius of a circle given the equation in expanded form.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Features of a circle from its expanded equation

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Graph a circle from its expanded equation | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given the expanded equation of a circle, graph the circle. For example, graph the circle whose equation is x²+y²+4x+8y+16=0.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Graph a circle from its expanded equation

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Circle equation review | Analytic geometry
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the standard and expanded forms of circle equations, and solve problems concerning them.
A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.
The equation of a parabola is derived from the focus and directrix, and then the general formula is used to solve an example.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Equation of a parabola from focus & directrix

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given the focus and the directrix of a parabola, derive its equation.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Equation of a parabola from focus & directrix

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Review your knowledge of the focus and directrix of parabolas.
Frequently asked questions about conic sections

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Focus and directrix of a parabola

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

unitChildren.translatedDescription: The cross-sections of a cone form several interesting curved shapes—circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas. Use the distance formula to relate the geometric features of the figures to their algebraic equations.

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Everything we've learned about angle relationships and proportions in other figures also applies in figures with circles and parts of circles.
Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs
Using triangles to create an informal argument for the area of a circle formula.
Watch Sal informally prove that all circles are similar by showing how we can translate then dilate any circle onto another.
Sal introduces arc measure including that they must sum to 360, conventions of minor and major arcs, and a comparison to arc length.
Watch Sal solve a few problems where he finds a missing arc measure.
Use the fact that the arc measures of a circle must sum to 360 degrees and other properties of angles that share a vertex to find missing arc measures.
Sal solves a few items where arc measures are given in equations, we have to find a variable, then use it to find an arc measure.
Use the fact that the arc measures of a circle must sum to 360 degrees and other properties of angles that share a vertex to set up equations and find missing arc measures.
Finding the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.
Watch Sal solve an example where he finds the central angle given arc length.
Relate the length of an arc to the circumference of a whole circle and the central angle subtended by the arc.
Solve four challenging problems that ask you to find arc length without directly giving you the arc measure.
Solve two challenging problems that ask you to find an arc measure using the arc length.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Derive using similarity the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Radians as ratio of arc length to radius

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: We can use the constant of proportionality between the arc length and the radius of a sector as a way to describe an angle measure, because all sectors with the same angle measure are similar.
Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.
Sal discusses the general approach to converting between radians and degrees and vice versa.

To convert from degrees to radians, multiply the number of degrees by π/180. This will give you the measurement in radians. If you have an angle that's 90 degrees, and you want to know what it is in radians, you multiply 90 by π/180. This gives you π/2.

To change from radians to degrees, you need to multiply the number of radians by 180/π. This number will help you switch between the two units. For example, if you multiply π/2 radians by 180/π, you will get 90 degrees.
Convert angle measures given in degrees to radians and vice versa.
Sal finds the fraction of an arc length out of the entire circumference using the radian measure of the central angle subtended by the arc.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Arc length as fraction of circumference

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal finds the length of an arc using the radius and the radian measure of the angle subtended by the arc.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Arc length from subtended angle: radians

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Solve problems related to radians and arc length like finding an arc length given the central angle and radius.
Solve three challenging problems that ask you to find arc length without directly giving you the arc measure.
Solve two challenging problems that ask you to find an arc measure using the arc length.
A worked example of finding the area of a circle's sector using the area of the circle and the central angle of the sector.
Relate the area of a sector to the area of a whole circle and the central angle measure.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal finds a missing inscribed angle using the inscribed angle theorem.
Practice the relationship between inscribed & central angles that are subtended by the same arc length.
Solve two challenging problems that apply the inscribed angle theorem to find an arc measure or an arc length.
Proving that an inscribed angle is half of a central angle that subtends the same arc.
Proving that an inscribed angle is half of a central angle that subtends the same arc.
Find the diameter of a circle using an inscribed right triangle.
One method using an inscribed angle intercepting a diameter of a circle.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Inscribed shapes: angle subtended by diameter

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Using either the inscribed angle theorem or the fact that two inscribed angles that intercept the same arc must be congruent.
Example showing supplementary opposite angles in inscribed quadrilateral.
Find missing angles and lengths in inscribed shapes.
Solve three challenging problems that apply properties of inscribed shapes to find an arc length or a missing angle.
Proof showing that a triangle inscribed in a circle having a diameter as one side is a right triangle
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: Right triangles inscribed in circles

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal uses the inscribed angle theorem and some algebra to prove that opposite angles of an inscribed quadrilateral are supplementary.
Sal proves that if a radius in a circle is drawn so it bisects a chord, then the radius is also perpendicular to that chord. The proof uses SSS congruence.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: radius is perpendicular to a chord it bisects

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Simple proof using right triangle-side-hypotenuse (RSH) congruence criterion to show that a radius perpendicular to a chord bisects it
Sal proves that the radius that connects the intersection point of a tangent line with the circle is perpendicular to the tangent line.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: Radius is perpendicular to tangent line

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Solve two problems that apply properties of tangents to determine if a line is tangent to a circle.
Solve two problems that apply properties of tangents to determine if a line is tangent to a circle.
Sal proves that two tangent segments to a circle that are drawn from the same outside point are congruent.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Proof: Segments tangent to circle from outside point are congruent

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal finds missing angles using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.
Sal finds a missing angle using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.
Sal finds a missing length using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.
Solve problems related to tangents of circles.
Solve two challenging problems that apply properties of tangents to find the radius of a circle with a tangent.
Solve two challenging problems that apply properties of tangents to find the perimeter of a circumscribing shape.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal constructs a square that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.
Sal constructs an equilateral triangle that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.
Sal constructs a regular hexagon that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Constructing regular polygons inscribed in circles

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Sal constructs a circle that inscribes a given triangle using compass and straightedge.
Sal constructs a circle that circumscribes a given triangle using compass and straightedge.
Sal constructs a line tangent to a circle using compass and straightedge.
Sal constructs a line tangent to a circle using compass and straightedge.
Frequently asked questions about circles

allOrderedChildren.translatedTitle: Constructing a line tangent to a circle

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

unitChildren.translatedDescription: Explore, prove, and apply important properties of circles that have to do with things like arc length, radians, inscribed angles, and tangents.

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Practicing finding area of 2D figures, volume of 3D figures, and comparing proportional relationships will help us apply what we know from simpler figures to more complicated solid figures.
Learn the names of common solid figures, the parts of those solids, and how we describe cross-sections of them.

The cross sections of 3D shapes are dilations of the original shape, centered at a specific point. The scale factor of the dilation depends on the height of the cross-section or the distance from the point on the base.
What happens when you slice vertically into a rectangular pyramid? What kind of geometric shape results?
Match 3D objects with their 2D cross-sections.
Learn about all the different ways we can obtain cross-sections of a cube.
Relate common 3D solids with their 2D cross-sections taken parallel, perpendicular, and diagonal relative to the base.
If you rotate a 2D shape about an axis, the shape will define a 3D object. Watch Sal rotating various 2D shapes and see what 3D objects he gets!
Visualize the 3D figure you could form by rotating a 2D figure around an axis.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: If two figures have the same height and the same width at every point along that height, they have the same area.
If two 3D figures have the same height and the same cross-sectional area at every point along that height, they have the same volume.
Cavalieri's principle tells us that if 2 figures have the same height and the same cross-sectional area at every point along that height, they have the same volume.
Determine when it is appropriate to apply Cavalieri's principle and use it to justify why certain figures have equal volumes.
The volume of a pyramid is a fraction of the volume of the rectangular prism that encloses it. We can find out what that fraction is by cutting a prism into several pyramids.
Where does the 1/3 come from in the formula for the volume of a pyramid? How does the volume of a cone relate? What about oblique pyramids (pyramids that lean to the side)?
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Volume of a pyramid or cone

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Use Cavalieri's Principle to establish that the formula for the volume of a cone is the same as the formula for the volume of a pyramid (1/3 * base area * height).
Use related volumes (using the volume of one figure to determine the volume of another).
Scale, dissect, and rearrange simpler figures to help find the volume of more complicated figures, including pyramids, oblique figures, and figures with different base shapes.
No matter what shape the base is, if we know the height and the area of the base of prism-like or pyramid-like solids, we can find their volume.

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Using the formulas for the volume of triangular prism and cube to solve some solid geometry problems.

curatedChildren.translatedCustomTitleTag: Volume of a cone (formula walkthrough)
curatedChildren.translatedDescription: The formula for the volume of a cone is V=1/3hπr². Learn how to use this formula to solve an example problem.
A cylinder's volume is π r² h, and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

The formula for the volume of a sphere is V = 4/3 π r³, where V = volume and r = radius. The radius of a sphere is half its diameter. So, to calculate the surface area of a sphere given the diameter of the sphere, you can first calculate the radius, then the volume.
Find volumes and surface areas of cylinders.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Volume and surface area of cylinders

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Calculate the volume of a grain hopper and then use the given rate to solve an applied problem.
It's time to mix and match!  Now that we can find volume in several basic shapes, let's combine them to see how we model more interesting and useful real figures.
Solve problems concerning real-world situations with the volumes of cones, cylinders, pyramids, prisms, and spheres.
Review the formulas for the volume of prisms, cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres.

Area or surface density is the amount of a quantity (often mass) per unit of area.
Density=Quantity/Area

Volume density is the amount of a quantity (often mass) per unit of volume.
Density=Quantity/Volume
Solve problems concerning real-world situations using your knowledge of volume, area, and density.
Frequently asked questions about solid geometry

allOrderedChildren.translatedDescription: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}
Test your understanding of {unit name}.

unitChildren.translatedDescription: Take your knowledge of geometry into new territory! In this unit, we'll explore three-dimensional shapes and all the fascinating properties they possess. Get ready to think outside the box (or, in this case, inside the cube)!

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Positive rotation angles mean we turn counterclockwise. Negative angles are clockwise. We can think of a 60 degree turn as 1/3 of a 180 degree turn. A 90 degree turn is 1/4 of the way around a full circle. The angle goes from the center to first point, then from the center to the image of the point.
Given a point and a definition of a rotation, plot the rotation on a coordinate plane or identify the coordinates of the rotated point.

To see the angle of rotation, we draw lines from the center to the same point in the shape before and after the rotation. Counterclockwise rotations have positive angles, while clockwise rotations have negative angles. Then we estimate the angle. For example, 30 degrees is 1/3 of a right angle.
Learn how to determine which rotation brings one given shape to another given shape.
Given a figure on the coordinate plane and a center of a rotation, find the angle for the rotation that maps one figure to the other.
Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, and he manually draws the image of that rotation.
Learn how to draw the image of a given shape under a given rotation about the origin by any multiple of 90°.
curatedChildren.translatedTitle: Rotating shapes about the origin by multiples of 90°

curatedChildren.translatedDescription: Given a figure on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, manually draw the image of that rotation.
